isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 9800 - LIFT AXLE SYSTEMS - SYSTEM DESCRIPTION - AXLE TYPES

svcprocinfo.para: Two types of lift axles are available: fixed (non-steerable) axles, and self-steering axles.

svcsubproc.title: FIXED AXLES
svcsubproc.para: Fixed axles do not allow the wheels to steer while cornering. This causes increased tire wear due to tire scrubbing while cornering, but it allows the axle design to be simple, requiring less maintenance. The fixed axle currently used has a 20,000 pound maximum load capacity and may be used as a tag axle or a single pusher axle. FIGURE 1 is an example of a fixed lift axle.

figure.caption: Figure 1. Example of a Fixed Lift Axle (Top View)

svcsubproc.title: SELF-STEERING AXLES
svcsubproc.para: The self-steering axles reduce tire wear, but are more complex than fixed axles. Self-steering axles are similar to front, non-driving, steering axles. Like a front axle, the steering arms and knuckles at the ends of the self-steer axle are connected by a tie rod so that both tires on the axle track together. A spring-loaded self-centering mechanism keeps the tires aimed straight ahead until the drag created by cornering causes the tires to deflect, or steer, in the direction that creates the least rolling resistance. As the direction of travel straightens out the self-centering mechanism returns the tires to their straight ahead position. FIGURE 2 is an example of a self-steering lift axle.
The self-steer axle currently used has a 13,200 pound maximum load capacity. The self-steer axle may be used in any lift axle location and in any combination.

figure.caption: Figure 2. Example of a Self-Steering Lift Axle (Top View)
